title: The Federal Reserve releases its daily H.15 interest rate data, providing the latest yields on Treasury bonds and market rates.
summary: According to our report, the Federal Reserve Board of Directors released its daily H.15 selected interest rate data on February 20, 2026. The report indicates that this release covers the nominal yields to maturity of Treasury bonds and inflation-hedging bonds, as well as several market interest rates, and is scheduled for release at 4:15 PM Eastern Time on a business day. The Fed also stated that this data provides current daily yield figures along with historical series and download tools to help the market track the direction of Treasury yields and key interest rates.
fullContent:
# Chief Intelligence Officer - Daily Brief
**Topic**: Latest economic and financial intelligence from major economies
**Time**: 2026/2/21 21:50

## Situation Overview
Welcome to the Daily News Channel, I'm Joe. Today we bring you 20 major events that have impacted global events in the past 24 hours, covering macroeconomic data, central bank decisions, bond market trends, foreign exchange and commodities, and cryptocurrency market dynamics. Follow along as we analyze these important developments around the world, keeping you up-to-date with the latest market and policy developments.

## Key Intelligence
### 1. The Federal Reserve releases its daily H.15 interest rate data, providing the latest yields on Treasury bonds and market rates.
- **Time**: 2026-02-20
- **Source**: Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System (FederalReserve.gov)
- **Summary**: According to our report, the Federal Reserve Board of Directors released its daily H.15 selected interest rate data on February 20, 2026. The report indicates that this release covers the nominal yields to maturity of Treasury bonds and inflation-hedging bonds, as well as several market interest rates, and is scheduled for release at 4:15 PM Eastern Time on a business day. The Fed also stated that this data provides current daily yield figures along with historical series and download tools to help the market track the direction of Treasury yields and key interest rates.
- **References**:
  - [1] [Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System (FederalReserve.gov)](https://www.federalreserve.gov/releases/h15/)

### 2. RMB and Liquidity Focus: PBOC Interest Rate Decision Included in Economic Calendar
- **Time**: 2026-02-20
- **Source**: FXStreet
- **Summary**: The report indicates that FXStreet's economic calendar updated on February 20, 2026, records the timing of the People's Bank of China's interest rate decisions. The page explains the monthly Loan Prime Rate (LPR) and the schedule of the central bank's monetary policy meetings. Furthermore, the entry explains the potential impact of these arrangements on the RMB and market liquidity, and provides historical data and future meeting previews to help traders track interest rates and policy pace.
- **References**:
  - [1] [FXStreet](https://www.fxstreet.com/economic-calendar/event/fa510216-a58a-4dba-93f7-0c05c1e5e3d1)

### 3. China's key macroeconomic calendar updated; housing prices, output, and consumption data to be released in sequence.
- **Time**: 2026-02-21
- **Source**: TradingEconomics
- **Summary**: According to our report, TradingEconomics' updated China Economic Calendar, released on February 21, 2026, lists several upcoming or recently released macroeconomic data points, covering key indicators such as housing price indices, industrial output, retail sales, fixed asset investment, unemployment rate, and foreign capital inflows. The calendar also provides the latest actual values and market expectations, allowing market participants to immediately assess the impact of GDP, industrial output, consumption, and real estate data on the short-term market.
- **References**:
  - [1] [TradingEconomics](https://tradingeconomics.com/china/calendar)

### 4. A week packed with UK output data has put market tensions, while slowing inflation and employment have increased expectations of interest rate cuts.
- **Time**: 2026-02-20
- **Source**: IC Markets; AMP; Saxo Bank
- **Summary**: According to a report compiled by this station, analyses from IC Markets, AMP, and Saxo Bank on February 20, 2026, indicated that the UK will have a week of intensive data releases from February 20th to 21st, including January CPI, employment, and retail sales. Reports suggest that consumer inflation has fallen to around 3.0% and the labor market is showing signs of cooling. These signals have prompted traders to raise the probability of a 25 basis point rate cut by the Bank of England in March. Market observers also believe that this data will be a key input for the Bank of England's next decision, influencing the pound and government bond prices.
- **References**:
  - [1] [IC Markets (20 Feb 2026); AMP (20 Feb 2026); Saxo Bank (20 Feb 2026)](https://www.icmarkets.com/blog/ic-markets-global-europe-fundamental-forecast-20-february-2026/) | https://www.amp.com.au/resources/insights-hub/weekly-market-update-20-02-2026 | https://www.home.saxo/content/articles/macro/market-quick-take---20-february-2026-20022026

### 5. Phnom Penh bonds are supported by fiscal space and short-term debt issuance bias, while declining inflation is putting downward pressure on yields.
- **Time**: 2026-02-20
- **Source**: Saxo Bank; IC Markets; AMP
- **Summary**: According to a report by this station, Saxo Bank, IC Markets, and AMP noted on February 20, 2026, that recent fiscal policy moves indicate more 'fiscal space' and a preference for issuing short-term government bonds. Their analysis shows that against the backdrop of falling inflation and expected monetary easing, these factors have collectively supported UK gilts and suppressed yields. However, market participants also cautioned that despite the favorable outlook, political risks related to local elections and policy credibility could still trigger renewed volatility.
- **References**:
  - [1] [Saxo Bank (20 Feb 2026); IC Markets (20 Feb 2026); AMP (20 Feb 2026)](https://www.home.saxo/content/articles/macro/market-quick-take---20-february-2026-20022026) | https://www.icmarkets.com/blog/ic-markets-global-europe-fundamental-forecast-20-february-2026/ | https://www.amp.com.au/resources/insights-hub/weekly-market-update-20-02-2026

### 6. Foreign Exchange Market Overview: The US dollar retreated, the euro was supported by policy divergence, and gold remained stable.
- **Time**: 2026-02-20
- **Source**: FinanceFeeds
- **Summary**: According to our report, FinanceFeeds' foreign exchange and macroeconomic overview on February 20, 2026, pointed out that the US dollar retreated due to concerns about stagflation in the US and the impact of tariffs. Reports also indicated that the euro strengthened due to policy disagreements between the European Central Bank and the Federal Reserve, while the yen rose due to trade data. Gold prices remained relatively stable, while the crude oil market consolidated. The article also listed key events that could potentially influence future foreign exchange and commodity flows.
- **References**:
  - [1] [FinanceFeeds](https://financefeeds.com/global-fx-market-summary-us-stagflation-fears-tariff-shock-jolts-dollar-ecb-fed-divergence-lifts-euro-gold-steady-20-february-2026/)

### 7. Market Brief: Softening US inflation pushes Treasury yields down, stock market fluctuates.
- **Time**: 2026-02-20
- **Source**: Yahoo Finance
- **Summary**: According to our report, Yahoo Finance, in its daily market review for February 20, 2026, noted that easing inflation pushed US Treasury yields to multi-month lows. Reports indicated that the S&P 500 fluctuated near key levels and declined slightly, while selling pressure related to artificial intelligence eased. The review also noted that geopolitical tensions continued to support oil prices, and strategists cautioned investors to remain cautious ahead of subsequent data releases.
- **References**:
  - [1] [Yahoo Finance (video)](https://finance.yahoo.com/video/2-20-2026-inflation-moderates-213314371.html)

### 8. Bitcoin whales are returning, and on-chain data suggests a V-shaped accumulation pattern.
- **Time**: 2026-02-21
- **Source**: StockTwits
- **Summary**: According to our report, on-chain data reposted by StockTwits on February 21, 2026, indicated that a large amount of Bitcoin was withdrawn from exchanges, amounting to approximately 60,000 to 100,000 coins over the past month. Observations suggest this is being interpreted as whale accumulation at lower prices. Market analysis also indicates that Bitcoin was trading at around $68,000 at the time of the report, and the decline in exchange balances is seen as a potentially bullish signal. If this buying pressure continues, it could provide upward momentum for the price.
- **References**:
  - [1] [StockTwits](https://stocktwits.com/news-articles/markets/cryptocurrency/bitcoin-v-shape-accumulation-whale-after-ethereum-tomlee/cZR8IThR4UG)

### 9. The White House held a closed-door meeting to discuss the CLARITY bill with representatives from the crypto industry and banking sector, and issued an ultimatum for March 1st.
- **Time**: 2026-02-20
- **Source**: MEXC
- **Summary**: According to our report, on February 20, 2026, the White House held a closed-door meeting in Washington, D.C., inviting representatives from the crypto industry and the banking sector. Reports indicate that the meeting focused on the CLARITY bill being pushed forward by Congress, with the White House issuing a March 1st ultimatum regarding the bill's timeline. According to MEXC, key issues discussed at the meeting included proposals to limit the yields of passive stablecoins. The meeting also noted that geopolitical tensions are complicating the legislative process, leading to greater uncertainty between the industry and regulators, which may affect the cooperation framework between crypto assets and banks in the short term.
- **References**:
  - [1] [MEXC](https://www.mexc.co/en-NG/news/758421)

### 10. The European Central Bank maintained its key deposit rate at 2% and raised its 2026 growth forecast.
- **Time**: 2026-02-09
- **Source**: Yahoo Finance
- **Summary**: According to our report, the European Central Bank (ECB) revised its 2026 economic growth forecast for the Eurozone upward to 1.2% from 1.0% in its latest forecast released on February 9th, while maintaining the key deposit rate at 2%. The report indicates that the ECB also kept its growth forecasts for 2025, 2027, and 2028 at around 1.4%, and projected HICP inflation of around 1.9% in 2026, slightly below the 2% target. The report suggests that policymakers believe maintaining interest rates in the short term is appropriate given the current economic resilience, while closely monitoring the impact of falling inflation and changes in financial conditions on policy.
- **References**:
  - [1] [Yahoo Finance](https://finance.yahoo.com/news/ecb-sees-stronger-eurozone-growth-151029869.html)

### 11. Eurozone growth resilience supports the ECB's more optimistic economic outlook.
- **Time**: 2026-01-06
- **Source**: Reuters
- **Summary**: The report, citing Reuters on January 6, indicated that despite export pressures, robust Eurozone growth in 2025, supported by domestic demand and consumption, has made the European Central Bank (ECB) more optimistic about the economic outlook. The report cited market and macroeconomic data, stating that this growth resilience has helped mitigate the immediate impact of upside risks to inflation, supporting the central bank's wait-and-see approach to monetary policy. Furthermore, this description echoes the central bank's subsequent adjustments to interest rates and expectations, providing empirical evidence for policy formulation.
- **References**:
  - [1] [Reuters](https://www.reuters.com/world/europe/euro-zone-inflation-dips-growth-holds-up-backing-ecbs-sanguine-narrative-2026-01-06/)

### 12. The European Central Bank released its February monetary policy decision materials and disclosed charts and data on financial and inflation data.
- **Time**: 2026-02-09
- **Source**: European Central Bank
- **Summary**: According to our report, the European Central Bank (ECB) provided updated charts and data, including the latest financial conditions index, HICP inflation decomposition, and sovereign wealth fund differentials, in its monetary policy decision-making materials released on February 9. The materials show that the central bank used the latest observations up to early February when assessing macroeconomic financial indicators and explained the interaction between current financial conditions, the inflation path, and macroeconomic risks. Reports indicate that this official material provides market participants with detailed background information on why the central bank chose to maintain interest rates and raise some growth forecasts.
- **References**:
  - [1] [European Central Bank](https://www.ecb.europa.eu/press/key/date/2026/html/ecb.sp260209~d8c520c2ff.en.pdf)

### 13. Lagarde discussed the challenges of stabilizing prices and productivity at the central bank's press conference on February 5.
- **Time**: 2026-02-05
- **Source**: European Central Bank (YouTube)
- **Summary**: According to our report, European Central Bank President Christine Lagarde explained the Governing Council's decisions and answered reporters' questions at the monetary policy press conference on February 5. The report indicates that Lagarde emphasized the central bank's commitment to ensuring inflation remains stable at around 2%, while pointing out that achieving higher long-term growth depends on productivity improvements. The report also shows that she assessed the impact of geopolitical and global supply chain risks on the Eurozone's outlook and stated that the policy stance will be dynamically adjusted based on data.
- **References**:
  - [1] [European Central Bank (YouTube)](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=2c6h9H5LRwU)

### 14. Consumer expectations for short-term growth have declined, but inflation expectations remain stable; the central bank is focusing on medium- to long-term risks.
- **Time**: 2026-01-08
- **Source**: Bloomberg
- **Summary**: According to a Bloomberg report on January 8th, a European Central Bank (ECB) poll showed that short-term consumer expectations for economic growth have declined, but overall inflation expectations remain unchanged. The report points out that this divergence makes it difficult for the central bank to make a judgment—weak short-term demand could suppress prices, but if inflation expectations become sticky, it poses a risk to medium-term price stability. The report indicates that the central bank is closely monitoring changes in the labor market and inflation expectations to determine its future policy path.
- **References**:
  - [1] [Bloomberg](https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2026-01-08/ecb-says-consumers-inflation-expectations-remain-unchanged)

### 15. Eurozone January Flash Report: Inflation Falls to 1.7%, Economic and Policy Game Intensifies
- **Time**: 2026-02-04
- **Source**: CNBC
- **Summary**: The report indicates that a CNBC news flash on February 4th pointed out that the Eurozone's January flash CPI fell to 1.7%, the lowest level since September 2024. The report cited economists who stated that this data dampened the need for further short-term interest rate hikes, but also suggested that underlying price pressures had not completely disappeared. It is also observed that central banks face a choice in interpreting this data: whether to wait for more evidence to confirm a decline in inflation, or to remain vigilant about potential service sector inflation and latent inflation signals.
- **References**:
  - [1] [CNBC](https://www.cnbc.com/2026/02/04/euro-zone-inflation-january-ecb-disinflation-concerns.html)

### 16. Lagarde emphasized the central bank's determination to keep inflation near the 2% target.
- **Time**: 2026-02-05
- **Source**: Bloomberg (video)
- **Summary**: According to our report, Bloomberg recorded European Central Bank President Christine Lagarde's remarks in a video report on February 5th. She reiterated the central bank's "determination" to ensure inflation returns to and stabilizes near the 2% target. The report shows that Lagarde emphasized data-driven decision-making and policy patience in explaining this position. The report also noted that the central bank will continue to assess data to determine whether and when to adjust the interest rate path to prevent inflation expectations from becoming unanchored.
- **References**:
  - [1] [Bloomberg (video)](https://www.bloomberg.com/news/videos/2026-02-05/ecb-determined-to-ensure-inflation-stabilizes-at-2-video)

### 17. Studies show that US tariffs may suppress inflation in the Eurozone, but interest rate cuts could offset the effect.
- **Time**: 2026-02-10
- **Source**: Reuters
- **Summary**: According to a Reuters report on February 10th, an analysis by European Central Bank economists stated that US tariffs on certain goods could exert downward pressure on Eurozone inflation through the demand channel. The report further pointed out that sectors affected by tariffs are typically more sensitive to interest rates, and if the central bank chooses to cut interest rates in the future, the effect could partially offset the downward pressure on inflation caused by tariffs. The report indicates that this research provides policymakers with a new perspective on weighing interest rate paths when facing external shocks.
- **References**:
  - [1] [Reuters](https://www.reuters.com/business/euro-zone-inflation-take-hit-tariffs-rate-cuts-could-offset-ecb-economists-find-2026-02-10/)

### 18. Sovereign debt spreads are near post-financial crisis lows, but further narrowing requires institutional reforms.
- **Time**: 2026-02-04
- **Source**: Reuters
- **Summary**: According to our report, Reuters published an analysis on February 4th stating that eurozone sovereign bond spreads have narrowed to near post-financial crisis lows. However, the report points out that without deeper institutional reforms—such as a banking union and co-borrowing facilities—further unification of spreads will remain difficult. The report also mentions that the market widely expects central banks to begin cutting interest rates later this year, an expectation already priced into current bond prices and spreads.
- **References**:
  - [1] [Reuters](https://www.reuters.com/business/finance/ultra-low-bond-spread-unity-still-out-reach-euro-area-2026-02-04/)

### 19. Rising consumer expectations for medium- to long-term inflation increase the difficulty of medium-term governance for central banks.
- **Time**: 2026-01-30
- **Source**: Reuters
- **Summary**: According to our report, a Reuters poll released on January 30th by the ECB showed that eurozone consumers have revised their five-year inflation expectations to a record high. The report points out that rising long-term inflation expectations could increase the challenges for central banks in achieving medium-term price stability, as rising expectations can affect wage negotiations and pricing behavior. The report indicates that regulators and monetary authorities will continue to monitor this indicator to prevent inflation expectations from becoming chronic and negatively impacting policy effectiveness.
- **References**:
  - [1] [Reuters](https://www.reuters.com/business/finance/euro-zone-consumers-up-5-year-inflation-forecast-record-high-ecb-poll-shows-2026-01-30/)

### 20. Eurostat's January estimate showed the eurozone's annual inflation rate at 1.7%.
- **Time**: 2026-02-04
- **Source**: Eurostat
- **Summary**: According to our report, Eurostat's estimates released on February 4th show that the Eurozone's annual inflation rate in January 2026 is approximately 1.7%, with varying contributions from sub-categories such as services, food, and energy. The report indicates that this official statistic provides the European Central Bank and the market with fundamental data to help determine the sustainability of the inflation trend and to provide a reference for the central bank to make more prudent judgments on the interest rate path.
- **References**:
  - [1] [Eurostat](https://ec.europa.eu/eurostat/statistics-explained/index.php/Inflation_in_the_euro_area)
